sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Ground beetles of the subfamily Lebiinae ( Carabidae ) of Guinea-Bissau: description of three new species and faunistic notes

SERRANO cE3c—Center for Ecology, Evolution and Environmental Changes & CHANGE — Global Change and Sustainability Institute, Departamento de Biologia Animal, Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade de Lisboa, R. Ernesto de Vasconcelos, Ed. C2, Campo Grande, 1749-016 Lisboa, PORTUGAL

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Abstract

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Three new species of ground beetles belonging to the genera
Arsinoe Laporte de Castelnau, 1835
,
Dontolobus Basilewsky, 1970
and
Lasiocera Dejean, 1831
( Coleoptera , Carabidae , Lebiinae ), respectively, from Guinea-Bissau are described:
Arsinoe aguiari
n. sp .
,
Dontolobus bivari
n. sp.
and
Lasiocera schwarzi
n. sp.
, together with illustrations of their habitus and aedeagus. Moreover, an annotated checklist of 35 species and subspecies of Lebiinae is provided, including data on general distribution, new country and new distribution records at country level. The list includes novel information from one entomological mission to that country carried out in 2009 and corrigenda data on previous published species. Further, dichotomic keys are made available for the identification of the Guinea-Bissau species of the
Arsinoe
,
Dontolobus
and
Lasiocera
genera. Some considerations on the distribution and conservation status of these beetles in Guinea-Bissau are also presented.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Resumo

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Neste trabalho são descritas três espécies novas para a ciência da Guiné-Bissau respectivamente dos géneros
Arsinoe Laporte de Castelnau, 1835
,
Dontolobus Basilewsky, 1970 e
Lasiocera Dejean, 1831
( Coleoptera , Carabidae , Lebiinae ):
Arsinoe aguiari
n. sp .
,
Dontolobus bivari
n. sp.
e
Lasiocera schwarzi
n. sp.
Uma lista comentada de 35 espécies e subespécies de coleópteros carabídeos Lebiinae da Guiné-Bissau é também apresentada, incluindo dados sobre a distribuição geral e sobre novos registos para o país e dentro do mesmo. Nesta lista estão incluídas as espécies amostradas durante uma missão entomológica realizada àquele país em 2009, assim como correcções a dados anteriormente publicados sobre esta subfamília. Além disso, são disponibilizadas chaves dicotómicas para a identificação das espécies e subespécies da Guiné-Bissau dos géneros a que pertencem as novas espécies. Algumas considerações sobre a distribuição e estado de conservação destes coleópteros na Guiné-Bissau são também apresentadas.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Key words : carabides,
Arsinoe , Dontolobus , Lasiocera ,
West Africa

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Introduction

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Ground beetles are a speciose group, including several subfamilies, one of which is the Lebiinae (Lorenz 2005, 2021). Within the twenty species of this subfamily that were included in Laferté-Sénectère (1849, 1850, 1853) monographic catalogue of the carabides of the former “Old Portuguese Guinea”, seven were described for the first time. One century later, Brivio (1957) published the results of collected Carabidae over four years (1953– 1956) by the Italian missionaires of the “Pontificio Istituto Missione estere di Milano”, recording nine species of Lebiinae (sensu Lorenz 2005) . More recently, Serrano (2009a) provided the results obtained from the study of the Lebiinae captured in several entomological expeditions carried out by the author to Guinea-Bissau (1983, 1992, 1995 and 2006).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
The aims of this study are: (a) describe three new species, belonging to the genera
Arsinoe Laporte de Castelnau, 1835
,
Dontolobus Basilewsky, 1970
and
Lasiocera Dejean, 1831
, respectively; (b) give an annotated checklist of the Lebiinae ( Carabidae ) captured during the entomological expedition carried out by the author to Guinea-Bissau in 2009; (c) provide several corrections to previous results published in Serrano (2009a) and; (d) provide dichotomous keys for the identification of the species of these genera
Arsinoe , Dontolobus
and
Lasiocera ,
found in Guinea-Bissau. Moreover, new faunistic records (genera and species) are reported for Guinea-Bissau and novel distribution data within the country is presented for most of the species here studied.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: This work follows others dedicated to the Guinea-Bissau tiger and ground beetles (e.g., Serrano 1996, 1999a, 1999b, 2003, 2005, 2009a, 2009b, 2009c, 2012, 2024). A historical overview on the study of its entomofauna was also provided by Serrano (2022). Guinea-Bissau orography, climate, major vegetation types and references to threats to its biodiversity can be found also in Biai (2015), CILSS (2016) and Serrano (2012), respectively.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Material and methods

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Field-work was carried out in the beginning of the wet season (June-July of 2009) in Biombo, Cacheu, Gabú, Quinara and Tombali Administrative Regions of Guinea-Bissau. Two methods were used: direct observation (abbreviation “DO”) and light trapping (abbreviation “LT”) to collect specimens. Photos of type material and relevant non-type material were kindly provided by the Musée Royal de l’Afrique Centrale (MRAC) of Tervuren (Belgium). The morphological study of adult specimens, including measurements of the new species, was performed with a Wild M5 stereomicroscope equipped with a dissecting microscope ocular micrometer. The habitus of the adult specimens of the new species were taken with a Sony A7 camera, a Canon MP-E 65mm Macro @ 2.8X lens and processed using Stacking software Zerene stacker, a stacking hardware custom rail, plus controller and Lighting Dual high CRI LED COBs.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The following measurements were collected: body length (posterior margin of labrum to apex of elytron), labrum length (from anterior to posterior margin along midline), labrum width (between the lateral margins in the widest region), head length (from posterior margin of labrum to anterior margin of pronotum), head width (between the lateral region of the eyes), pronotum length (from anterior to posterior margins along midline), pronotum width (between the lateral margins in the widest region), right elytron length (basal margin near scutellum to apex along the suture) and elytron width (measured across both elytra at their widest point).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: For each new species the sex of the study specimens was followed by the label information in quotation marks. Every line of a label is separated by a backslash symbol “\”, individual labels by a double backslash symbol “\\”. Remarks and comments (e.g., color of label) are found in square brackets. If there is handwritten or typewritten information on a label it is marked with an “[h]” or [t], respectively.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: For the remaining species/subspecies is provided information concerning its description (author and date). The general distribution is given by alphabetical order of country names abbreviations while for Guinea-Bissau is indicated (1) previous Administrative Regions records and (2) new Administrative Regions records. The lists of abbreviations of African countries and Guinea-Bissau Administrative Regions were provided, jointly with a map showing the Administrative Regions of Guinea-Bissau in Serrano (2022, Tables 1–2; Fig. 1). For the material examined of each species/subspecies: the localities (with geographic coordinates, altitude and Administrative Region), the sampling date, the number and sex of specimens, the sampling method and the depository collection are provided, whenever possible. Finally, remarks on species/subspecies distribution and comments on the specimens examined (e.g., general ecology) are also included, if available. Some species/ subspecies are syntopic and to avoid the repetition of the same information on ecology throughout the text (remarks section), this information is given in Table 1. The table provides only the field-work localities visited in 2009 with two or more syntopic species/subspecies. The new genera/species/subspecies records for GuineaBissau are marked with an asterisk (*).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: I follow the nomenclature given in Lorenz (2021). The tribes, subtribes, genera, subgenera and the species/ subspecies names are organized by alphabetical order.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Material examined: Cacheu (IBAP) (12º 15´29.59´´ N, 16º 09´24.45´´ W, 25 m alt.) (CAC), 25.VI.2009, 1 male, LT, A. Serrano leg., ASC.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks. The species is distributed throughout the sub-saharan northern territory of Africa, reaching the Saudi Arabia in the Peninsula of the same name (Lorenz 2021). The adult male specimen of Cacheu fits very well this species. Chaudoir (1876) referred that the species is distributed throughout the “Possessions françaises et portugaises sur le Sénégal et l`Abyssinie”. However, strangely, the species was not reported for the “Guinée portugaise” by LaFerté-Sénectère (1853). Now, I confirm its presence in Guinea-Bissau, increasing the number of
Tetragonoderus species
to seven for this country (LaFerté-Sénectère 1853; Serrano 2009a) (Tables 1–2).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Remarks. The species is distributed throughout West Africa, but is known from ETI in northeastern Africa also (Lorenz 2021). It is a very common species in the northern half of Guinea-Bissau (Serrano 2009a) and the adult specimen was captured by LT within a secondary open forest (Table 1). The species is active until the beginning of the dry season (Serrano 2009a).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Remarks. The species is widely distributed throughout western, central and eastern Africa (Lorenz 2021). It was first reported for Guinea-Bissau by Serrano (2009a). The adult specimen was captured by LT within a semihumid forest (Table 1). It is a new species record for the TOB Administrative Region, Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage

*
Somoplatus Dejean, 1829

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The genus is distributed throughout the Afrotropical and Oriental Regions (Lorenz 2021). The African species were reviewed by Basilewsky (1986) and later by Schüle (2009). There are 14 and one species recognized for the former and the later Regions, respectively (Lorenz 2021). Ecological remarks were provided by Basilewsky (1986). The genus was not recorded for Guinea‒Bissau, but here are four new records for this country.

sec.p: Remarks. The species presents a scattered distribution throughout West and Central Africa (Lorenz 2021). The adult specimen was sampled by LT within a periurban environment and it is a new genus/species record for GuineaBissau (Table 1).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Remarks. The species is widely distributed throughout western, central, southern, and eastern Africa (Lorenz 2021). It was described originally from France based on specimens captured in the port of Marseille (Mulsant & Godart 1867). The adult specimens were captured by LT within semi-humid forests in the beginning of the rainy season and it is a new genus/species record for Guinea-Bissau (Table 1).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Remarks. The species was only known from Ivory Coast (Schüle 2009; Lorenz 2021). The adult male specimen fits the description of this species, including the aedeagus. It was captured by LT within open secondary forest in the beginning of the rainy season during the 2006 entomological mission to Guinea-Bissau. Formerly unidentified but now, it is a new genus/species record for Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Remarks. The species is widespread throughout western and central Africa, reaching KEN in eastern Africa (Basilewsky 1986; Lorenz 2021). The adult male specimen matched very well the description of this species, including the aedeagus. It was captured by LT within open secondary forest at the beginning of the rainy season during the 2006 entomological mission to Guinea-Bissau. This formal description recognises this species as a new genus/species record for Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage

*
Anomotarus Chaudoir, 1875

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
The genus is distributed throughout the Afrotropical, Australian and Oriental Regions (Lorenz 2021), but as yet there has been no global revision of the genus. However, the Australian and Oriental assemblages were revised by Baehr (2004a, 2006, 2009, 2011, 2013) resulting in five subgenera, including the nominal one within the genus (
Amplitarus Baehr, 2009
,
Anomotarus
, Dromiotes Jeannel, 1949,
Lithostrotus Blackburn, 1894
, Nototaurus Chaudoir, 1875 and
Rubritarus Baehr, 2009
) (Lorenz 2021). Prior to this study the genus was not recorded from Guinea‒Bissau yet, but now there is one new record for this country within the Dromiotes subgenus.

Anomotarus ( Dromiotes ) maculipennis (Mateus, 1970)

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Remarks. The species is known throughout central and south-eastern Africa (Mateu 1970; Lorenz 2021). The presence in Guinea-Bissau increases its known distribution to include the northwestern Africa region. The male adult specimen matches very well with the description of the species, including the aedeagus (see Mateus 1970). It was captured by LT within an open secondary forest in the beginning of the rainy season (Table 1), and is a new genus/species record for Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks: A widespread species throughout western and north-eastern Africa (Lorenz 2021). It was recorded previously for the old “Guinée portugaise” by LaFerté-Sénectère (1849). Brivio (1957) and Serrano (2009a) later recorded the other species of the
Cymindoidea Laporte de Castelnau, 1831
genus (
C. virgulifera Chaudoir, 1875
) known from Guinea-Bissau. The adult specimens from Mampatá Forea-Nhocobá reported in Serrano (2009a) as
C. virgulifera
actually belong to
C. bisignata
. The adult specimens were sampled by LT within open secondary forests at the beginning of the wet season (Table 1). It is a new species record for GAB and TOB Administrative Regions, Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Remarks. The species is known throughout West Africa, as well as in Saudi Arabia (Serrano 2009a; Lorenz 2021). It was reported for the first time for Guinea-Bissau by Serrano (2009a). The adult specimens were captured by LT within open secondary forest (Banhinda) or semi-humid forests (P.N. Lagoas da Cufada) at the beginning of the wet season (Table 1). It is a new species record for the CAC Administrative Region, Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks. The species has a scattered known distribution throughout western, central and eastern Africa (Lorenz 2021, Shi & Liang 2023). The species has been misidentified as
P. ferruginea (Chaudoir, 1878)
in previous works (e.g., Basilewsky 1955; Serrano 2009a). Recently, Shi & Liang (2023) clarified the external morphologic characters of the
Parena ( Parena ) plagiata
group (
P. ferruginea
,
P. plagiata Motschulsky, 1864
and
P. africana
), allowing the segregation of these species. The adult specimens recorded in Serrano (2009a) as
P. ferruginea
and the recent specimens match very well with
P. africana
, including the aedeagus. Taking this into account,
C. ferruginea
must be excluded from the known entomofauna of Guinea-Bissau. The adult specimens were sampled by LT within open secondary forests (Contuboel, Coli, Banhinda) or semi-humid forests (P.N.L. Cufada) at the beginning of the wet season. See also the syntopic species/subspecies for the 2009 field localities (Table 1). It is a new species record for the CAC Administrative Region, Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Subtribe Pericalina Hope, 1838

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The genus is endemic to the Afrotropical Region, enclosing twenty-six species from the continental part and one from Madagascar (Lorenz 2021). There has not been a complete revision of the entire genus. However, Péringuey (1896, 1898) and Burgeon (1937) revised the southern Africa and the former Belgian Congo species, respectively. Basilewsky (1970a) described several species from West Africa and more recently Facchini (2011, 2017) described new species from several African countries. The genus was already recorded for Guinea‒Bissau (Serrano 2009a), but I describe a new species for this country.

sp. n.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Differential diagnosis: Head, disc of the pronotum and elytra are black; the pronotum sides, antennae, mandibles (part), palps and tarsi are reddish-brown; femurs and tibiae dark red-brown; each elytron with two yellowish subrounded spots, one subhumeral and the other subapical, not divided from the contralateral one by the suture; head punctured, dorsal surface with strong longitudinal furrows in the lateral sides above the eyes and in the disc of frons; lateral margin of pronotum very large, punctured and distinctly and transversally furrowed; distinctive shape of aedeagus (Figs 2a–b).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Description

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Length of the holotype: 9.4 mm.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Head (Fig. 1a). Much wider as long (male: length 1.52 mm, width: 2.14 mm; female: length 1.55 mm, width: 2.32 mm), scarcely punctured and glabrous, without microsculpture, strong longitudinal furrows on the sides above the eyes, lesser but visible on frons, vertex sparsely punctured, decreasing to rear; mandibles of medium length; labrum wider than long (male: length 0.21 mm, width: 0.64 mm; female: length 0.27 mm; width: 0.67 mm), lightly punctured, anterior margin slightly arcuate, six submarginal setae along the anterior edge; clypeus sparsely but distinctly punctured, anterior margin slightly arcuate, one long and fine brown-yellowish seta in the middle of each side near lateral, posterior margin convex; mentum largely triangular, glossa with two setae at apex, paraglossae longer than the glossa, pubescent on the external side; palps microreticulate, the labial dichetes, last palpomeres trunk, not dilated apically; eyes large and prominent, temples short, narrowing obliquely towards the neck; antennae short, not surpassing posteriorly the base of the elytra, 1 st antennomere twice longer than the 2 nd , the 3 rd and the 4 th are the same length, but almost twice longer than the 2 nd , 4 th antennomere pubescent from the distal half and slightly longer than the 5 th antennomere, the remaining ones with pubescence, decreasing very gradually to the penultimate, the last antennomere longer and more or less acuminate; one pair of supraorbital long ferruginous setae on each side.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Thorax . Pronotum strongly transverse (Fig. 1a), 1.8–1.9 times as long as wide (male: length 1.76 mm, width: 3.17 mm; female: length 1.86 mm, width: 3.44 mm), widest point just before the middle; anterior margin arcuate, slightly narrower than the base, lateral margins moderately rounded anteriorly, narrowed posteriorly, very slightly sinuated just anterior to the posterior angles; anterior angles rounded, slightly protruded; posterior angles obtuse, sharped at apex, protruding outwards; margins ridged all-around, including the middle of the posterior margin which is slightly emarginated; surface of disc smooth among the moderately dense small and medium punctures; two setae in each lateral margin, one at the maximum width and one at the posterior angle; longitudinal median sulcus fine, clearly visible in the median part, not reaching the anterior and posterior margins; anterior transverse sulcus very faintly distinct, masked with small longitudinal grooves; posterior transverse sulcus not clearly visible; lateral surface between disc and lateral margins very large, strongly arched and raised, deepened posteriad, stronger punctuation than the discal one, forming oblique irregular meshes, stronger in the posteriad half; scutellum triangular, scarcely punctured.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Elytra (Fig. 1a) subparallel-sided, 1.3 times as long as wide (male: length 6.14 mm, width: 4.82 mm; female: length 6.67 mm, width: 5.28 mm), widening slightly towards the posterior third; each elytron with two yellowish sub-rounded spots, one subhumeral, extending from the 3 rd to the 8 th interval and the other subapical, extending from the 1 st to the 4 th interval; the first seven striae visible, well-marked, finely punctured, reaching the base, outer

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 8 th and 9 th striae less marked, incomplete; scutellar striae scarcely punctured, well visible between suture and 1 st striae; each elytron ridged all-around from the sutural apex to the scutellum, not toothed in the shoulders, forming a curve; apical margin not sinuous; interval surfaces shiny, glabrous, moderately convex, distinctly punctured, smooth among punctures; setiferous basal pore present; two setiferous discal pores on the 3 rd interval; umbilicate series constituted by 14 setiferous pores (6 aggregate behind the shoulders, 3 central and 5 subapical); two apical setae, one of which inserted in a smaller umbilical pore;

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Ventral surface . Head underside, lateral surfaces of pro-, meso- and metasternum and metepisterna blackish, pronotum lateral underside, central surfaces of pro-, meso- and metasternum and abdomen brownish or dark brownish, silky; gula and ventral and lateral sides of genae (neck) smooth, glabrous; prosternum and propleura scarcely punctured, each puncture with an erected minute seta, mesosternum punctured in the middle, meshed in the lateral declivities, metasternum smooth in the middle, gradually punctured in the lateral surfaces; metepisterna elongated, narrowed posteriorly and punctured; prosternal apophysis not bordered; elytral epipleura simple, enlarged and excavated longitudinally in the first third, narrowing roughly to the apex; abdomen surface very finely punctured, not microreticulate; last abdominal sternite with two pairs of submarginal setae (male and female).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Legs (Fig. 1a) slightly elongated; male first four fore tarsomeres slightly dilated, underside felted with two rows of squamulose setae; first four tarsomeres of intermedium and hind tarsi pubescent underneath; female first four tarsomeres pubescent underneath, the first four fore not dilated in female; tarsomere 4 th not bilobed; onychium only with lateral setae underneath (male and female); claws simple.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Male genitalia (Figs 2a–b). Median lobe medium sized (length: 2.1 mm), stout, the anterior and middle regions largely bossed in the right side (dorsal view); ostium large, membranous, displaced to the right side; apical lamella short, rounded (dorsal view), acuminate (lateral view) at apex; basal bulb developed, slightly bossed in the right side; ventral margin strongly bossed in the middle, apex bending very slightly downwards (lateral view) (Fig. 2a); endophalus with a very diffuse small sclerite in the left side of the first third (dorsal view); left paramere large, rounded, longer than wide, without any distal tooth (Fig. 2a).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Etymology. This species is named in honour of Dr. Carlos Aguiar (Lisboa, Portugal) a friend and well-known specialist of Carabidae , who has collaborated with the author for more than 30 years in the study of the ground beetles of Portugal.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Distribution . Only known from Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks . Considering the general shape and some external morphological characters (e.g., general colour, yellowish elytral spots pattern, lack of microreticulation)
Arsinoe aguiari
n. sp .
seems to be close to
Arsinoe flavosignata (Gory, 1833)
and
Arsinoe rugiceps Facchini, 2017
. The new species is also more akin with the later species by the blackish femurs (yellowish in the former species), the head with strong longitudinal ridges on the sides near and above the eyes (these ridges are barely visible in
A. flavosignata
) and the very wide lateral sides of the pronotum (not so wide in
A. flavosignata
). However, some other external characters allow separating these two species from
A. aguiari
n. sp .
Arsinoe rugiceps
presents the surface of frons punctured (not or very slightly in the new species), the lateral margin of pronotum more rounded in the middle and the apical margin of elytra slightly sinuate (not in the new species) (see Fig. 1a and Fig. 2 in Facchini 2017). Regarding
A. flavosignata
, in addition to the differences already indicated above, it also differs from the new species by a smaller length, the 2 nd , 3 rd and 4 th antennomeres black (reddish in the new species), the lateral margin of pronotum not sinuated just anterior to the posterior angles (very slightly sinuated in the new species), the pronotal surface less punctured and without lateral oblique ridges (stronger punctured and with lateral oblique ridges in the new species, the elytral surface among striae scarcely punctured (stronger punctured in the new species), elytral spots more reduced than in the new species and a different shape of median lobe of aedeagus.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The new species differs from the remaining African species by the median lobe shape, among other external morphological characters.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks. The species is distributed throughout western Africa (Facchini 2011; Lorenz 2021). It was previously reported for Guinea-Bissau as
Arsinoe sp.
by Serrano (2009a). The adult specimens, all females from different localities of Guinea-Bissau, match very well the description of this species (see Facchini 2011). The specimens were captured by LT within semi-humid forests (QUN localities) and open secondary forests (Coli and Banhinda) at the beginning of the wet season (Table 1). It is a new species record for Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The genus was described by Basilewsky (1970c) and is endemic to the Afrotropical Region, enclosing nine species (Basilewsky 1970c; Facchini 2012, 2017). An identification key for five of these species was provided by Facchini (2017). The genus was not recorded for Guinea‒Bissau, but I describe a new species.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Differential diagnosis: head, including mandibles, labrum, palps, antennae and legs reddish-brown; pronotum darker, elytra brown-blackish with yellow-reddish lateral margin, each elytron with a yellowish oblique subhumeral spot that reaches the base and a yellowish subapical spot on intervals 1 st –4 th ; body glabrous, winged; head distinctly punctured; pronotum transverse, denser and finely punctured on the disc, lateral margins narrowing posteriad in a straight line up to the posterior angles; male genitalia (Figs 2c–d).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Description

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Length of the holotype: 7.0 mm.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Head (Fig. 1b). Wider as long (males: length 1.52 mm, width: 1.70–1.79 mm; females: length 1.28-1.38 mm, width: 1.68-1.79 mm), distinctly punctured and glabrous, without microsculpture, slight longitudinal furrows on the sides near the eyes, not visible in frons, vertex punctured; mandibles of medium length; labrum wider than long (males: length 0.26–0.27 mm, width: 0.53–0.54 mm; females: length 0.24–0.27 mm; width: 0.51–0.54 mm), very slightly finely punctured, anterior margin just distinctly arcuate in the middle, six setae close to the anterior margin; clypeus slightly bossed longitudinally, sparsely but distinctly punctured in the middle, anterior margin straight, one long and fine anteriad brownish seta near lateral margin, posterior margin slightly convex; mentum largely triangular, glossa with two setae at apex, as well as two minute central setae very close between, paraglossae longer than the glossa, pubescent on the external side; palps microreticulate, with a few very small scattered setae, last palpomeres moderately narrowed towards the apex, labial palps dichete; eyes large and prominent, temples short, narrowing obliquely towards the neck; antennae short, not surpassing posteriorly the base of the pronotum, 1 st antennomere twice longer than the 2 nd , the 3 rd and the 4 th with the same length, but almost twice longer than the 2 nd , 4 th antennomere pubescent from the distal half and with the same length of 5 th antennomere, the remaining ones pubescence, with the same length, the last antennomere longer and more or less acuminate; one pair of supraorbital long dark ferruginous setae on each side.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Thorax . Pronotum strongly transverse (Fig. 1b), 1.8–1.9 times as long as wide (males: length 1.33–1.38 mm, width: 2.43–2.50 mm; females: length 1.31–1.39 mm, width: 2.43–2.56 mm), widest point clearly before the middle; anterior margin arcuate, slightly narrower than the base, lateral margins angulate at the maximum width, narrowed posteriorly almost in a straight line up to the posterior angles; anterior angles rounded, slightly protruded; posterior angles strongly obtuse, not sharped at apex; posterior margin finely ridged, slightly emarginated, not lobed in the middle; surface of disc with transverse microreticulation among denser and smaller punctures than the head; two setae in each lateral margin, one at the maximum width and one at the posterior angle; longitudinal median sulcus fine, clearly visible in the median part, not reaching the anterior and posterior margins; anterior and posterior transverse sulci very faintly distinct, not clearly visible; lateral surface between disc and lateral margins very large, widened posteriad, with isodiametric reticulation, coarser punctuation than that of the disc; scutellum triangular, with isodiametric reticulation, scarcely punctured.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Elytra (Fig. 1b) short, 1.2–1.3 times as long as wide (males: length 4.42–4.49 mm, width: 3.52–3.55 mm; females: length 4.22–4.42 mm, width: 3.42–3.58 mm), maximum width approximately in the middle; each elytron with a yellowish oblique subhumeral spot extending from the 3 rd –7 th intervals, reaching the base in the 5 th –7 th intervals and a yellowish subapical spot, extending from the 1 st –4 th intervals; eight striae visible, shallow, finely punctured, reaching the base, outer 8 th less marked anteriad; scutellar stria scarcely punctured, well visible between suture and 1 st stria; each elytron ridged all-around from the scutellum to the ending of the 2 nd stria just before the sutural apex, not toothed in the shoulders, forming a curve; apical margin very slightly sinuous; interval surfaces silky, glabrous, not convex, finely but distinctly punctured, isodiametric microreticulation among punctures; setiferous basal pore present; two setiferous discal pores on the 3 rd interval, the anterior near 3 rd stria, the posterior near 2 nd stria; umbilicate series constituted by 14 setiferous pores (6 aggregate behind the shoulders, 2 central and 6 subapical); two apical setae, one of which inserted in a smaller umbilical pore.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Ventral surface . All underside brownish, glabrous; gula and mesosternum smooth; ventral and lateral sides of genae (neck), prosternum and propleura faintly and scarcely punctured, some punctures of prosternum with pale minute setae dressed and directed posteriad; metasternum smooth in the middle, gradually punctured in the lateral surfaces; metepisterna elongated, narrowed posteriorly, smooth; prosternal apophysis not bordered; elytral epipleura simple, enlarged and slightly excavated longitudinally in the first third, narrowing roughly to the apex;

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: abdomen surface very scarcely and finely punctured, smooth among punctures, transverse microreticulation only visible in the last abdominal sternite at high magnification; last abdominal sternite of males and females with 2 pairs of subapical setae.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Legs (Fig. 1b) slightly elongated; male first three fore tarsomeres slightly dilated, underside felted with two rows of squamulose setae, mesotibiae on the internal side with subapical notch; female fore tarsomeres not dilated; male and female first tarsomere of intermedium and hind tarsi pubescent underneath, remaining tarsomeres including the onychium only with lateral setae underneath; claws simple.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Male genitalia (Figs 2 c–d). Median lobe of aedeagus medium sized (length: 2.0 mm), very slightly sinuous on the ventral side (lateral view), concave in the lateral side (dorsal view); ostium small, membranous, displaced to the left side; apical lamella short, rounded (dorsal and lateral views); apex bending very slightly upwards (lateral view) (Fig. 2 c); basal bulb thin; endophallus without visible sclerites; left paramere longer than wide, rounded at apex, slightly sinuous on the ventral side, without any distal tooth (Fig. 2 c).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Etymology. This species is named in honour of Dr. António Bivar de Sousa, a friend, a specialist on Dermaptera and Lepidoptera, who I have participated with on several entomological missions carried out in Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Distribution . Only known from Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks .
Dontolobus bivari
n. sp.
is easily segregated from
Dontolobus pallidus (Burgeon, 1937)
,
Dontolobus sachtlebeni (Basilewsky, 1942)
and
Dontolobus mirei Basilewsky, 1970
by the pronotal angular lateral margins, corresponding to the maximum width instead of the rounded lateral margins of those three species. Moreover, the elytra spots drawing of the new species and the other are completely different.
Dontolobus setosanalis Basilewsky, 1970
has a pronotum like that of
D. bivari
n. sp .
, but is easily separated by the number of submarginal setae pairs in the last abdominal sternite (6–7 vs 2) and by the elytral spots (dented bands vs more or less rounded bands).
Dontolobus bivari
n. sp .
can also be distinguishable from
Dontolobus aemiliae Facchini, 2012
and
Dontolobus trinotatus Facchini, 2012
for a distinctly more transverse and lighter coloured pronotum. The new species differs also from
D. aemiliae
by the lateral margins of the pronotum which are not sinuated towards the base and the posterior obtuse angle largely rounded (slightly sharp in the latter species). Moreover, the three species differ from the shape and features of median lobe of aedeagus (see Figs 2c–d and Figs 8, 9 in Facchini 2012).
Dontolobus labroexcisus Facchini, 2017
is easily segregated from the new species by the bigger size, the darker colour of the head and pronotum and the anterior margin of labrum with small but distinct V-shaped median incision.
Dontolobus similis Facchini, 2012
differs also from the new species by the darker colour of head and pronotum and the anterior margin of pronotum almost straight (distinctly arcuate in the new species). Moreover, these three species differ from the shape and features of median lobe of aedeagus also (see Figs 2 c–d and Figs 8, 10 in Facchini 2017). Finally, taking into account the general shape and some external morphological characters (e.g., general colour, yellowish elytral spots),
D. bivari
n. sp .
seems to be close to
Dontolobus ivorensis Facchini, 2012
. However, the head and pronotum punctuation, the shape of clypeus and features connected with the median lobe of aedeagus (cf. Figs 2 c–d and Fig. 9 in Facchini 2017), easily allow the separation of these two species.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks: The species has a scattered distribution throughout western, central, and southern Africa (Serrano 2009a; Lorenz 2021). The adult specimens of Coli (Quebo) identified as
L. trimaculatus
, after a new careful analysis, was revealed to belong to a new species of the genus
Dontolobus Basilewsky, 1970
(see
D. bivari
n. sp .
). The adult specimen was captured by LT within a semi-humid forest at the beginning of the wet season (Table 1). It is a new species record for QUN Administrative Region, Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks. The species has a scattered known distribution throughout western and central Africa (Jansen 1968; Lorenz 2021). The male adult specimen of Bissorã was misinterpreted and identified as
Coptodera ( Coptoderina ) rugiceps (Murray, 1857)
and by Serrano (2009a). Taking this into account,
C. rugiceps
must be excluded from the known entomofauna of Guinea-Bissau. The male adult specimen matches very well with the description of
Neocoptodera championi
, including the aedeagus (Jansen 1968). This species is a new record for Guinea-Bissau.

Phloeozeteus (Serrano 2009a)
. The two Guinea-Bissau specimens matches well with
Singilis bedimo
, including the aedeagus. The adult specimens were captured by LT within open secondary forests. It is a new species record for Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks. The species is scattered throughout West, Central and northeastern Africa (Serrano 2009a; Lorenz 2021). The first record was for Guinea-Bissau by LaFerté-Sénectère (1849) under the name of
Casnonia senegalensis Dejean, 1831
and then later reported in several localities of Guinea-Bissau by Serrano (2009a). It seems a common species in this country. The adult specimens were captured by LT within urban environments (Cacheu) and open secondary forest (Banhinda) (Table 1). It is a new species record for CAC Administrative Region, Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
*
Lasiocera Dejean, 1831

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The genus is distributed throughout the Afrotropical and Oriental Regions (Lorenz 2021). There is no formal revision of the genus, but a key for the southern species of Africa was provided by Serrano et al . (2017). There are 11 and three species recognized for the former and the later Regions, respectively (Lorenz 2021). The genus was not recorded for Guinea‒Bissau until I described a new species for this country.

Lasiocera nitidula Dejean, 1831

sec.p: Remarks. The species is widespread from western to northeastern Africa (Lorenz 2021). The adult specimens were all found near the Béli locality during the day in open, moist patches within savannah and captured by DO (Table 1). It is a new genus and species record for Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Lasiocera schwarzi
n. sp.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: (Figure 1 c)

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Type series. Holotype, female; “Banhinda (PNT Cacheu \ Guiné-Bissau 27.06.2009 \ Col. A. Serrano\\ A. Serrano leg.” \\ “Holotype female\
Lasiocera
\
schwarzi
n. sp. \ A. Serrano det. 2023” [t] [h] [red card].

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Diagnosis. Body elongate, parallel, slightly convex and greenish-bronze (Fig. 1c); head and pronotum integument strongly punctate, surface among punctures smooth with sparce micropunctures visible at high magnification; elytra intervals transversally rugose, surface microreticulate. Pronotum oblong-ovate shaped (Fig. 1c). A long longitudinal band in the anterior half of elytra, posterior half with a reduced elytral band (Fig. 1c).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Description. Length of Holotype: 4.32 mm.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Head. Triangular (Fig. 1 c), 1.1 times wider than long (length: 1.09 mm, width: 0.98 mm), greenish olive, deeply punctate, posteriad more closely, surface intervals almost smooth, slightly and distinctly micropunctate, visible at high magnification; mandibles and labrum brownish dark; eyes large, prominent; palpi brownish, apical half of the last articles darker, last article of both palpi fusiform, sharp at the tip; labrum with anterior margin triangularly emarginated; frontal furrows indistinct, lateral surface between antennae insertion and inner ocular suture with slightly longitudinal ridges; frons slightly convex, occiput slightly concave; antennae (1 st –6 th antennomeres) brownish, 4–5 long bristles just below the joints, scape 2.7 times longer than wide (length: 0.35 mm, width: 0.13 mm), pedicele 1.2 times longer than wide (length: 0.11 mm, width: 0.09 mm), 3 rd antennomere 2.1 times longer than wide (length: 0.21 mm, width: 0.10 mm), 4 th antennomere 2.2 times longer than wide (length: 0.22 mm, width: 0.10 mm), 5 th antennomere 2.4 times longer than wide (length: 0.24 mm, width: 0.10 mm) and 6 th antennomere 2.6 times longer than wide (length: 0.26 mm, width: 0.10 mm). Cephalic chaetotaxy (large setae). Labrum with three pairs of setae gradually shorter from external to inner sides, one pair laterally on clypeus and two pairs of supraocular setae present over each eye.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Thorax . Pronotum (Fig. 1c) 1.3 times longer than wide (length: 1.10 mm, width: 0.83 mm), greenish olive, shiny, closely and deeply punctate, surface intervals almost smooth, micropunctures visible at high magnification; narrower than head, oblong-ovate shaped, slightly rounded in the sides, concussively widest in the middle; apical and basal margins not margined, lateral margins with complete and distinct margination in the two first thirds since the anterior angles, reaching the posterior angles, proepisterna well visible from above in the two first thirds; apical margin slightly emarginated, apical angles largely rounded, not protruded; lateral margins slightly subparallel, followed by a sinuosity before the roundly right basal angles, posterior margin straight; median line absent, anterior and posterior transverse sulci indistinct; one marginal seta situated in the end of first half, the posterior marginal seta absent.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Elytra (Fig. 1 c) 1.79 times longer than wide (length: 3.10 mm, width: 1.73 mm), greenish olive dark, dull and with punctual metallic reflections; wider than pronotum, humeral angles broadly rounded; elongate and parallel, dorsally moderately convex, truncated obliquely behind, posterior obtuse angle slightly produced in a short spine, apical margin with 10 small denticles from the posterior angle to the sutural angle; striae deeply punctate, intervals narrow and convexes, transversely rugose, surface distinctly microreticulate; yellowish patches: a long longitudinal band in the anterior half of elytra on 5 th –7 th intervals and other small longitudinal band on 5 th and 6 th intervals; three setiferous punctures situated at 3 rd interval, one at basal ¼, other at median region and the last one at the beginning of the last ¼.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Ventral surface. Blackish-bronze, shiny; genae sparsely finely punctate, glabrous; proepisterna closely and deeply alveolo-punctate in the upper sides, becoming less densely punctate towards the ventral region; sternum glabrous; elytral epipleura smooth with some sparse and deeply punctures at first half; abdominal segments sparsely micropunctate, the first two covered laterally with sparce dressed short hairs.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Legs (Fig. 1c). Slender, yellowish, almost transparent; knees, apical region of tibiae and tarsi brownish dark; trochanters black.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Intraspecific variation . Not available.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks . The new species is akin of
Lasiocera asmara Basilewsky, 1962
(Fig. 1d) and
Lasiocera mirei Basilewsky, 1970
(Fig. 1e), described from Eritreia and Cameroon, respectively (Basilewsky 1962, 1970; Lorenz 2021), by the general habitus shape (cf. Figs 1c–e).
Lasiocera schwarzi
n. sp .
is easily separated from the former species by the pronotum that is more oblong, laterally less inflated, with the larger elytral patches (cf. Figs 1c–d) and from the later from the elytral antero-lateral conformation and the elytral patches (cf. Figs 1c, 1e).
Lasiocera schwarzi
n. sp.
by the pronotum shape and singular elytral patches is easily segregate from the remaining species.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Etymology. This species is dedicated in a modest homage to Engº Carlos Schwarz (late, former director of “Departamento de Pesquisa Agrária” (DEPA) and to his daughter Cristina Schwarz [former Coordinator of “Instituto de Biodiversidade e Áreas Protegidas” (IBAP) Guinea-Bissau] by the support that they gave to some of our fieldwork in Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Key to the Guinea-Bissau species of
Lasiocera

L . nitidula Dejean, 1831

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
- Pronotum narrower, slightly oblong-ovate; elytra slightly convex, intervals smaller, elytra yellowish dots/patches (Fig. 1 c); posterior margin of elytra dentated; legs yellowish, knees of femora and tarsi dark brownish............
L. schwarzi
sp. n.

sec.p: Remarks. The species is known only from four West African countries (Serrano 2009a; Lorenz 2021). It was described from the old “Guinea portugaise” by LaFerté-Sénectère (1849) without precise localities and then reported later from two localities in Guinea-Bissau by Serrano (2009a). All the adult specimens were captured by LT within semi-humid forests (Table 1).

(BIB), 22.VII.2009, 1 female, DO, A. Serrano leg., ASC.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks. The species is only known from three West African countries (Lorenz 2021). The first record of this species from Guinea-Bissau by LaFerté-Sénectère (1849) was under the name of
Casnonia lineola Dejean, 1831
and later reported for several localities of Guinea-Bissau by Serrano (2009a). However, some adult specimens recorded for this country under
S. lineola
in Serrano (2009a) were misidentified, belonging to
S. nigeriana nigeriana Liebke, 1938
. This species seems common in this country and adults are active during the wet season, occurring at the edges of bogs within open savannah patches, open secondary forests, or even semihumid forests. See also the syntopic species/subspecies for the 2009 reported sites (Table 1). It is a new species record for BIB and CAC Administrative Regions, Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Distribution : BFO, GBI, NRE, RCH.

sec.p: Historic records:

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Remarks. The species is polymorphic. Lorenz (2005) recognized three subspecies, including the nominal one. The nominotypical is known from four West African countries (Basilewsky 1968; Lorenz 2021). It was reported from the Old Portuguese Guinea by Brivio (1957), later Basilewsky (1968) and Serrano (2009a) briefly referred to that species as known from this country. Some adult specimens captured during the 1992, 1995 and 2006 entomological missions to Guinea-Bissau (see material examined) were misinterpreted and identified as
S. lineola
by Serrano (2009a). As the precedent species,
S. nigeriana nigeriana
seems common in Guinea-Bissau and the adults are active during the wet season, occurring at the edges of bogs within open savannah patches, open secondary forests, or even semi-humid forests also. See also the syntopic species/subspecies for the 2009 reported sites (Table 1). It is a new species record for QUN and TOB Administrative Regions, Guinea-Bissau.

S. corrusca
. Later Brivio (1957) and Serrano (2009a) reported the species for some localities in Guinea-Bissau. The adult specimens were captured by LT within semi-humid forests (Table 1). It is a new species record for QUN Administrative Region, Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Remarks. The species have a very scattered and widespread distribution throughout Africa south of Sahara (Serrano 2009a; Lorenz 2021). It was first reported for Guinea-Bissau by Serrano (2009a). The adult specimens were captured by LT within semi-humid forest (Jemberem) and secondary open forest (Quinhamel) (Table 1). It is a new species record for the BIB Administrative Region, Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
The genus is distributed worldwide and the African species were revised by Basilewsky (1989) under the Perigonini tribe. Lorenz (2005) then recognized the eight genera given by Basilewsky (1989) at the subgenera level. Within the African
Perigona ( Perigona )
and the
Perigona ( Euripogena ) Basilewsky, 1989
subgenera, there are six and three recognized species, respectively (see Basilewsky 1989; Baeher 2004b; Serrano 2008; Lorenz 2021). The genus
Perigona
was never reported from Guinea‒Bissau.

sec.p: Remarks. The species is widespread throughout western, central, and eastern Africa and has also been recorded in France and the Netherlands (Basilewsky 1989; Lorenz 2021). It is a new genus/species record for Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Discussion

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The Lebiinae are one of the most speciose subfamilies of ground beetles, with 7115 species/subspecies distributed worldwide (Lorenz 2021). Guinea-Bissau, a small African country, exhibits a relatively numerous and important entomologic biodiversity (e.g., see references in Serrano 2022). A historical overview on the study of the GuineaBissau Lebiinae was provided by Serrano (2009a). A total of 51 species/subspecies of Lebiinae , belonging to 30 genera have previously been recorded for Guinea–Bissau (LaFerté-Sénectère 1849, 1850, 1853; Brivio 1957; Basilewsky 1968; Serrano 2009a). This recent study of the Lebiinae captured during June and July, 2009 added five genera and sixteen species (three new to science and thirteen new records) to this country. Therefore, the total number of Lebiinae recorded for Guinea-Bissau is now 65 species and subspecies, belonging to 34 genera (Table 2).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The threats to biodiversity in Guinea-Bissau, as well as for most of the African countries has been highlighted on several occasions (e.g., see references in Serrano 2022, 2024; Jankielsohn 2023). The factors that are related to biodiversity losses in Guinea-Bissau are well known (e.g., fragmentation and/or destruction of its forests by land farming, excessive logging, fuelwood extraction and illegal hunting, e.g., Oom et al . 2009; Temudo et al . 2020; Ferreira da Silva et al . 2021). Moreover, the Reserves and Natural Parks of Guinea-Bissau have some weaknesses regarding administrative and logistical support (e.g., Costa et al . 2013).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The global decline in insects is a reality (Cardoso et al. 2019, 2020; Janzen & Hallwachs 2021; Kawahara et al . 2021), but the little that is known for Guinea-Bissau entomofauna points in the same direction (e.g. Serrano 2012). The assessment of the conservation status for the Lebiinae of this country, as was mentioned in previous works for other groups of beetles from Guinea-Bissau (e.g., Serrano 2012, 2022, 2024), is not possible without the actual data.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Like other groups of Coleoptera , the majority of Lebiinae species found in Guinea-Bissau occur throughout West and/or Central Africa or West-Central-East Africa. Some species seem to have more restricted distributions (Guinea-Bissau and one or two of the neighbouring countries, such as Mauritania, Senegal, Guinea or Republique of Ivory Coast) (e.g.,
S. ivoirensis
,
C. risbeci ganganus
,
S. bedimo
) and still others have a disjoint distribution (North-western Africa and Republique of Congo or Angola and Republic of South Africa or even East Africa) (e.g.,
S. amplicollis
,
S. septentrionalis
,
P. rufula
,
L. garambae
,
L. verisimilis
,
A. laevigata
,
L. compressus
). Interestingly, only one species (
A. maculipennis
), is unknown from West Africa, but was found in Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Many species of
Lebiinae ( sensu Lorenz 2005)
have been recorded from Guinea-Bissau without indication of any precise locality (LaFerté-Sénectère 1849, 1951, 1953; Chaudoir 1876) or from a single locality, based on one or very few specimens (Brivio 1957; Serrano 2009a). Considering the known localities reported for each species/ subspecies, the Administrative Regions with the most species richness are TOB (S=36), followed by CAC (S=23), OIO (S=20), BAF (S=13) and GAB and QUN (both S=10). The remaining Administrative Regions (BIB, BIS and BOL) present only 0–2 reported species/subspecies (Table 2). Unfortunately, there is little data concerning the distribution of seven species/subspecies within Guinea-Bissau (Table 2). Since the captures of M. Bocandé in the former “Guinée portugaise” (LaFerté-Sénectère 1949; Chaudoir 1876), these species have never been recorded subsequently for any locality in Guinea-Bissau (Table 2). The lack of records for BOL, which includes the insular component of Guinea-Bissau (archipelago of Bijagós), is probably due to the under sampling of this Administrative Region, as well as the BIB and BIS Administrative Regions, which suffer from increasing human pressure on the environment.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The present research has significantly improved the knowledge of the regional distribution of many species/ subspecies in Guinea-Bissau. Especially the sampling in fragments of shrubby savannah, open secondary forests and semi-humid forests, suggesting that there are Lebiinae communities associated with each type of habitat (Table 1).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Recommendations to minimize the negative impact on Guinea-Bissau biodiversity and human populations were pointed out several times in previous works (e.g., Serrano 2022). Climate changes on the tropical and subtropical ecoregions in Africa, including Guinea-Bissau (Beaumont et al . 2011) are increasingly worsening for the human populations (USAID 2018), as well as to biodiversity (e.g., Torres et al. 2010; Serrano 2012; Vasconcelos et al . 2015; Sintayehu 2018). Once again, it is highly recommended that actions that lead to the deforestation or fragmentation of habitats be avoided at least in the Reserves and Natural Parks of Guinea-Bissau.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Considering the known world richness of Lebiinae ground beetles (Lorenz 2021), the diversity of species from Guinea-Bissau is not very impressive (Table 2). However, with further studies this number would likely increase, and obtaining more faunistic and ecological data. Continued field work must be done in sites poorly prospected or not visited yet (e.g., southwestern and southeastern regions of the Tombali and Gabu Administrative Regions, more insular parts of Guinea-Bissau). Future research targeting these beetles will surely result in new and interesting findings.
